Developing countries can take several actions to mitigate the negative effects of the EU's trade policies, including:

1. Pursuing diversification of their export basket - Developing countries should seek to diversify their export basket by promoting exports of goods and services which are less vulnerable to competition in the EU's internal market.

2. Promoting regional economic integration - By promoting regional economic integration by forming economic blocs or free trade areas, developing countries can create larger markets, reduce trade costs and increase coordination to compete effectively with other economies.

3. Strengthening domestic industries - By strengthening their domestic industries, developing countries can increase their competitiveness in the global market, this is done by investing in human capital, infrastructure development, innovation and implementing reforms on property rights.

4. Negotiating favorable trade agreements - Developing countries should negotiate favorable trade agreements with the EU by pushing for reductions in trade barriers and ensuring their inclusion in trade agreements that take into account their particular interests.

5. Seeking technical assistance - Developing countries can seek technical assistance from international organizations such as UNCTAD, the World Bank, and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to help them develop better trade policies and strategies that can mitigate the negative effects of the EU's trade policies.

Overall, it is important for developing countries to adopt proactive measures to mitigate and overcome the challenges faced as a result of the EU's trade policies to fully utilize the benefits of such policies.
